Award.AwardTitle: DIP: 'Hard Fun' Learning Mathematics: Stimulating Number Sense

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on development of number sense in 7 to 11 year old students through a 3D action game that will train the brain. The project tests a hypothesis that playing a number-sense action game can help children learn beyond the game, making them better overall at number-line sense, precision of numerosity, speed of numerical judgments, and ability to multitask numerical tasks. The innovation is twofold: a game, adapted from first-person shooter games, to train number sense, and a platform that makes it easy to vary aspects of the game (e.g., repetition, speed, number of possibilities) to be able to analyze what is it that is making a difference with respect to learning. Research is identifying the qualities of computer games that will train the brain to be automatic in its judgments and at qualities of experiences that promote such automaticity.

This project aims to promote fundamental mathematical competence in a way that makes the mathematics learning feel effortless and genuinely fun. In particular, the aim is to help children develop number sense, an ability to very quickly make estimates and numerical judgments. Such capability is key to keeping up in mathematics; children without that sense tend to lose interest in mathematics because mathematical computation becomes too frustrating. Training number sense, and, in turn, fostering mathematical performance, should allow more learners to think of themselves as "good at math." Cultivating a child's interest in mathematics from a young age has been identified as key to feeding STEM career paths.

The vehicle for promoting such mathematics learning is a new type of video game with foundations in first-person shooter games. Rather than shooting, players cast spells that require quick numerical estimates. There is reason to believe that such a game will be as engaging as first-person shooter games are. First-person shooter games have been shown to increase attention and executive control in adults, the kinds of cognitive skills known to foster academic achievement. Because engaging video games will reach and be played by a wide range of children; such a game has potential to reach at-risk populations who most need to better develop their number sense and those important skills. The intent is for the game to be used in informal settings, providing a complementary tool for educators to foster mathematics skills. Research that is done in the context of this game will identify the characteristics of game play that promote skill automation, foundational knowledge that is needed to provide a road map for creating child-friendly consumer video games to improve other important aspects of core cognition beyond number sense.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 15 years, research has accumulated documenting the potential positive impact of what we have termed “action video games” (typically first or third person action-packed shooter games) on different aspects of cognition. Positive impact of such game play has been documented in domains as varied as how well one sees, pays attention, multi-tasks or mentally rotates objects in one’s head. Importantly, this genre of video game play benefits more these skills than other video game genres (for example social games or puzzle games). Yet, a vexing issue concerns the ingredients in action video games that together produce these positive outcomes. The existing commercial action video games used in research studies so far are largely black box systems, with carefully crafted experiences unable to be modified, even slightly, by research teams wishing to compare the impact of variable game mechanics. 

Our aim was therefore to create a game engine accessible to researchers and that implements the main features of an action video game (1) in a manner where those features can be selectively manipulated by scientists (e.g., can be turned on/off; can be increased/decreased) and (2) where the game is situated in a world that is attractive to 8-12 year olds (both males and females).

 

To this end, our team performed several focus group studies to document the video game genres that children and their parents prefer to play. Of special concern is the fact that the action game genre is much more attractive to boys than to girls, a fact that potentially adds to pre-existing sex-based differences in foundational skills that underlie STEM such as mental rotation or magnitude estimation.  In a series of focus groups, we therefore explored how the core action mechanics could be made more attractive to girls as well as to parents. The outcome of this research was shared with several game developers to identify possible scenarios or video game worlds that would engage 8-12 year olds. A major hurdle we faced as the project developed was the realization that fully implementing one of these scenarios in a rich and semi-professionally executed video game would require a budget of about $1.5 million.

 

Simultaneously, we developed a web-based framework that sits on top of and extends a Unity3D video game development platform. Using this framework, optimized for a custom crafted first person 3D action game called 'eleMental",  over 40 parameters are exposed to researchers to modify how the game behaves, enabling variant testing against multiple research measures. This framework allows researchers to log into the management website, register research subject accounts, easily customize parameter values that drive the 'eleMental' game behavior, and deploy that new version of the game to all or a subset of existing accounts with a few simple steps. Profiles of gameplay settings can be saved as research conditions, to be able to test multiple conditions with groups of study participants quickly and easily. This game has begun to be used to evaluate the game mechanics that best foster brain plasticity. This has required solving several challenges, including the fact that although in principle all 40 parameters can be independently manipulated, many of the games generated in this large space at best deliver very poor play (and at worse are somewhat unplayable). A systematic evaluation of game playability as parameters of interest are modified according to our pre-specified hypothesis of game mechanics of interest has therefore been needed. Moreover, the usual evaluation of game play on cognition rests on extended training studies where one version of the game requires at least 3 months per participant to be evaluated. This pace is too slow as we need to iterate and compare many different game settings and thus we have begun to develop and validated alternate ways to proceed.

 

This work provides important methodological and practical considerations for the broader field of video game-based intervention. It highlights several challenges, including the relatively high cost of producing and distributing a video game experience that is truly immersive and engaging, the very delicate balance between game play ingredients that deliver such experience putting limits on how a video game experience can be deconstructed for the sake of scientific inquiry, and the difficulty of generating a scenario that both integrates key game play dynamics and is found to be enjoyable by both boys and girls within the 8-12 year old range.
